org.hs.jfc
Class HotStation

java.lang.Object
  |
  +--org.hs.jfc.HotStation
public class HotStation
extends Object

The HotStation facilitates the various processes of HotComponent data exchange. It is designed with the expectation that a single instance of a HotStation will serve an application. Configuration fo the HotStation is done through the properties parameter to its constructor, and with the methods setPickModifiers(int modifiers), setPutModifiers(int modifiers) and setHoldModifiers(int modifiers). Register your components and containers with the register() methods. Note that the HotStation can only apply its current cursor when the mouse is over your container if that container is registered with the station; even if it contains no HotComponent`s.

It may be possible to share a station across multiple JVMs, or to create interaction between components registered in separate stations, but I have tried neither.

Field Detail

COOL_COLOR

public static Color COOL_COLOR
This color is used for the background of the cursor when no component is currently hot-selected. Change it if you must, but please try to maintain the intended contrast (e.g., puce and mauve are not recommended choices for hot and cool colors).

PLAIN_CURSOR_FILE

public static final String PLAIN_CURSOR_FILE
Properties key for the plain cursor; associate it with the java.io.File containing your plain cursor image (must be in standard .gif format) in the TreeMap of properties you pass to the station constructor.

See Also:

LINK_CURSOR_FILE

public static final String LINK_CURSOR_FILE
Properties key for the "link" cursor; associate it with the java.io.File containing your "link" cursor image (must be in standard .gif format) in the TreeMap of properties you pass to the station constructor.

See Also:
Constant Field Values

HOT_COLOR

public static final String HOT_COLOR
Properties key for the hot color; associate it with the java.awt.Color you choose for your application's hot color in the TreeMap of properties you pass to the station constructor. The hot color is applied to the current mouse cursor when a component has been hot-selected, and the mouse cursor is currently over a potential drop location. It is also used to create the hot border, which is applied to potential drop recipients (via HotComponent.setBorder()) when the hot mouse cursor is over them.

See Also:
Constant Field Values

WARM_COLOR

public static final String WARM_COLOR
Properties key for the warm color; associate it with the java.awt.Color you choose for your application's hot color in the TreeMap of properties you pass to the station constructor. The warm color is applied to the current mouse cursor background when a component has been hot-selected, but the cursor is currently not over a potential drop location.

See Also:
Constant Field Values

BLANK_COLOR

public static final String BLANK_COLOR
Properties key for the "blank color"; associate it with the java.awt.Color you choose for your application's "blank color" in the TreeMap of properties you pass to the station constructor. The "blank color" is the transparent backdrop of your cursor images. Any pixels in those images that are set to the "blank color" will be made transparent by the HotStation in the instantiation of its cursors. The "blank color" itself will never appear in any HotStation cursor, so it may be visible in your raw cursor image.

See Also:
Constant Field Values

SWAP_COLOR

public static final String SWAP_COLOR
Properties key for the "swap color"; associate it with the java.awt.Color you choose for your application's swap color in the TreeMap of properties you pass to the station constructor. The swap color is the mutable background of your cursor images. Any pixels in those images that are set to the swap color will be re-colored by the HotStation with the cool, warm and hot colors in the instantiation of those three versions of each cursor type. The swap color itself will never appear in any HotStation cursor, so it may be visible in your raw cursor images.

See Also:
Constant Field Values
Constructor Detail

HotStation

public HotStation(TreeMap properties)
The HotStation constructor expects the parameter properties to contain the keys (public constants of this class) PLAIN_CURSOR_FILE, MOVE_CURSOR_FILE, COPY_CURSOR_FILE, LINK_CURSOR_FILE, HOT_COLOR, WARM_COLOR, BLANK_COLOR and SWAP_COLOR. See those constants for more information.

Method Detail

setPickModifiers

public void setPickModifiers(int modifiers)
Set the keyboard modifiers (i.e., SHIFT/CTRL/ALT) that will indicate a HotComponent pick to the HotStation; default is InputEvent.VK_ALT.

setPutModifiers

public void setPutModifiers(int modifiers)
Set the keyboard modifiers (i.e., SHIFT/CTRL/ALT) that will indicate a HotComponent put to the HotStation; default is InputEvent.VK_ALT.

setHoldModifiers

public void setHoldModifiers(int modifiers)
Set the keyboard modifiers (i.e., SHIFT/CTRL/ALT) that will indicate to the HotStation that the current hot selection should be held beyond the forthcoming put operation; default is InputEvent.VK_ALT | InputEvent.CTRL_MASK.

register

public void register(Container container)
Register container with the HotStation, so that it obtains the HotStation's updates to the cursor.

registerAll

public void registerAll(Container container)
Register container, and all of the containers and HotComponent`s it contains (HotStation will traverse the entire tree).

register

public void register(HotComponent component)
Register component with the HotStation.

unregister

public void unregister(Container container)
Remove container and all its components (containers and HotComponent`s) from the HotStation. They will no longer respond to station activity.

unregister

public void unregister(HotComponent component)
Remove component from the HotStation; it will no longer respond to station activity.

getLastPointPicked

public Point getLastPointPicked()
Get the coordinates of the point at which the last HotStation pick operation occurred. Useful for lists and trees.

getLastPointPut

public Point getLastPointPut()
Get the coordinates of the point at which the last HotStation put operation occurred. Useful for dropping into lists and trees.
